video.title: C++ Tutorial for Beginners - Full Course
video.description:
This course will give you a full introduction into all of the core concepts in C++. 

Want more from Mike? He's starting a coding RPG/Bootcamp - https://simulator.dev/

⭐️ Contents ⭐
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:38) Windows Installation
⌨️ (0:04:54) Mac Installation
⌨️ (0:08:44) Setup & Hello World
⌨️ (0:12:29) Drawing a Shape
⌨️ (0:19:55) Variables
⌨️ (0:31:43) Data Types
⌨️ (0:39:15) Working With Strings
⌨️ (0:49:00) Working With Numbers
⌨️ (0:59:41) Getting User Input
⌨️ (1:05:32) Building a Calculator
⌨️ (1:09:28) Building a Mad Libs
⌨️ (1:13:45) Arrays
⌨️ (1:20:03) Functions
⌨️ (1:29:47) Return Statement
⌨️ (1:35:22) If Statements
⌨️ (1:47:15) If Statements (con't)
⌨️ (1:55:58) Building a Better Calculator
⌨️ (2:02:20) Switch Statements
⌨️ (2:10:47) While Loops
⌨️ (2:18:53) Building a Guessing Game
⌨️ (2:29:18) For Loops
⌨️ (2:38:32) Exponent Function
⌨️ (2:45:21) 2d Arrays & Nested Loops
⌨️ (2:54:55) Comments
⌨️ (2:59:11) Pointers
⌨️ (3:13:26) Classes & Objects
⌨️ (3:25:40) Constructor Functions
⌨️ (3:34:41) Object Functions
⌨️ (3:41:43) Getters & Setters
⌨️ (3:54:04) Inheritance

Course developed by Mike Dane. Check out his YouTube channel for more great programming courses: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvmINlrza7JHB1zkIOuXEbw

🐦Follow Mike on Twitter: https://twitter.com/GiraffeAcademy

🔗The Giraffe Academy website: http://www.giraffeacademy.com/

⭐️Other full courses by Giraffe Academy on our channel ⭐️
💻C: https://youtu.be/KJgsSFOSQv0
💻Python: https://youtu.be/rfscVS0vtbw
💻SQL: https://youtu.be/HXV3zeQKqGY
💻Ruby: https://youtu.be/t_ispmWmdjY
💻PHP: https://youtu.be/OK_JCtrrv-c

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Hamzeh Nasreddine
replies.text:
Hello, 
Can anyone explain for me why did we put 
In 02:26:21
!outOfGuesses rather than outOfGuesses.
Shouldn't it be: while(secretNumber!=guess&& outOfGuesses)without ! before outOfGuesses.
Which means that while secret number isn't equal to guess and outOfGuesses=false(initial value) we continue the loop until outOfGuesses=true which is logical.
But when we put ! Before outOfGuesses the logic becomes: while outOfGuesses is true(opposite of false) we continue the program until it's true which doesn't make sense!
Am I right or I'm missing some point.

topLevelComment.author: Jaime Medina
topLevelComment.text: I really don't understand having to include the person in the video. It looks rather silly and adds nothing to the content; moreover, it takes up space and makes the actual code much smaller on the screen. The surface area of the presentation should be focused the subject matter and not this talking head. The clipping around him for the backdrop looks quite awkward and distracting as well. The presentation in general does not look professional. With regard to the content, I've watch 3 other C++ tutorials to get as much content as possible, and this is by far the weakest exposition of the language. The delivery of the course by this young man is amateur at best. I did not love his delivery IMHO. I felt a bit too off the cuff and imprecise. In fact, after watching it, I really only have one question: is it awesome? Is it really awesome? He didn't say if it was awesome enough times for me to believe it was totally awesome. Next time work it in a few more times.

replies.author: jx35yt
replies.text:
i think if you put outOfGuesses it just takes it as its true, thats why later on in 02:27:01 he says if(outOfGuesses){cout << "You lose";}
because hes trying to say that if you are out of guesses, then you lose. so i think c++ just takes it that its automatically true. 
so in that case, putting !outOfGuesses means that while you're not out of guesses, the loop will continue also. 
hope this helps

topLevelComment.author: Paddy
topLevelComment.text:
It's impressive how difficult it was for me to learn programming from scratch. I started C and quitted, C++ and quitted, got into Unity and C# and really made progress in learning programming trough C#. Then i needed to learn Python for School and it was really easy to learn and i was way ahead of my classmates because i knewed some concepts. 
Now 1 Year later i need C++ for an Project at my Work, one of the langueges is quitted because i thought it's to tuff for me but tbh more then half of the course i understand easilly and was a bit bored because i knew all the basic concepts. 

That helps me a bit with my Imposter Syndrom, i thoght im too bad for C++, practiced C# and Python a while and learning C++ is now so easy for me. 
Good Course !

Maybe you can add an C++ Course with QT for an GUI Application if its possible.

I just want to say that in my job I write SQL coding every day and I’m branching out now learning C++ just as a hobby currently, and this video is seriously one of the best instruction videos.

I just love his way of teaching, it’s excellent.  Precise, not overly wordy and simple, and the best thing is he runs his query after every example so we can clearly see the output.  

Seriously he is the best.  Great speaker and presenter.

Just wonderful teaching.

topLevelComment.author: HPIC PR
topLevelComment.text:
HELP please.

Interrogative:

In the EXPONENT for loop example, when you declare i=0, does this mean:
•begin at index position 0 (or the first character), or,
•continue looping as long as the power (or exponent) is greater that 0?

2:45:46

replies.author: Ryze
replies.text: Glad to see you understand, RIP that c++ doesn't have a when function.

replies.author: HPIC PR
replies.text: ​@Ryze Thank you! for the detailed explanation.  So i is a placeholder (I visualize this as a "starting point" that will continue to increase until it is no longer less than powNum, if you will?).  I understand the mechanic with the "result" equation; "result" is equaled to 1, then it is multiplied by the base and assumes this new product value for the next iteration.  This seems clear.  I was confused with i but now I see this is neither a character position identifier nor an instruction for looping.  It's merely a starting point for your function.

replies.author: Ryze
replies.text: Basically, the principal is that there is a number that starts a zero and there is a power number (exponent). Another thing before we go in depth is that a "for" loop is basically a steroid while loop + if statement. the variable I is just a place holder. It's saying that when i is equal to pownum, stop multiplying result by itself x basenum. For example lets use values. basenum = 2, and pownum is 3. (8 Is The Answer).  for i = 0; i++ (due to the increment at the end of the for statement) < pownum; increment. Summary: i is just a placeholder so that WHEN we reach the value of pownum we stop. for i = 0, i < pownum; increment. Entering the loop --> result (previously basenum x basenum or at the start, 1) = itself (result) * basenum (2). 2 = 2*2 (Not comparison operator but assignment.) Both of your bullet points are incorrect. Continue looping as long (the placeholder) i is less than the powNum. Languages don't have a "when" statement, so in place they use a for. I hope you can understand, if not visit the official docs.

Just a minor comment: At ~2:07:52, you stated if you don't add the "break;" for a case...the program will continue "checking" the conditions. Actually, it falls though the cases and will execute code of other cases until a "break;" is reached. No checking will occur.

Great tutorial though. Straight forward and to the point. Also provides motivation for using various aspects of the language.

topLevelComment.author: Milky Bone
topLevelComment.text:
I learned python a few months ago to make a discord bot. I felt like it was a really great way to get started with programming, but I really had a hard time visualizing the use for the syntax that python used. It was hard for me to think that way. C++ feels a lot more flexible to me. I feel like I can play around with it a lot more and I enjoy playing around with it a lot more than I felt I did with python. 

The analogy I came up with is this: Python hands you a small box full of tools and tells you to build a house. C++ does the same thing but gives you more tools than python. Both can build a house, and some people can see how they're going to build that house with the tools python gives you, but C++ gives you different ways to build that house and really lets you choose how to do it.

topLevelComment.text: Could someone please explain to me what exactly the line setRating(aRating); does? Im kinda lost. It is at 3:51:00

replies.author: A typical YouTube user
replies.text:
It allows you to change the "rating" from the main function while also checking if the rating is valid. You can't do that with "avengers.rating = " because "rating" is private (aka you can't access it from other functions). By limiting the access to "rating" and only allowing to change it through a function you can also check if the rating your input is valid (the "if" statement).
Hope this explanation wasn't too complicated and hope it helps.

I tried several things and finally did a getline (); before the getline (cin, name); and that worked for me. I did some searching and it appears that when you use cin >> age; before the getline (cin, name); that the i.O. Stream still has a blank or something on it and that has to be cleared away before the getline (cin, name); The getline(); clears the input stream so it will work properly. topLevelComment.author: Puncifikator3
topLevelComment.text: C++ is one of the most complex languages out there and that's good. C++ is WAYYYY faster than Python and is therefore preferred by companies where speed is key (like for example banks for financial transactions, security systems and other areas). when you want it to be as fast as possible, C++ is the best mediator between being user-friendly and being fast. it's the halfway point between assembly language and python

replies.author: Nick's Gmail
replies.text: @InC Yeah no one cares if their bank direct deposit hits at 3:00:05 compared to 3PM on the dot. Speed doesn't matter, security and reliability do. My dad works in IT for one of the biggest banks in the world, and I've talked to him about this before. He said that a lot of the back end work is legacy, and pretty hard for anyone to work on. This means that while you want all of those things, you also want a language that is going to stick around. Java, C++, and so on aren't going anywhere for at least 15 years, if at all.

replies.author: Rocket
replies.text: Actually C executes faster afaik, but it's harder to code in than C++

replies.author: InC
replies.text: I think you got it mixed up, the slow stuff is financial and security. Stuff like games, which can have 100s or 1000s of objects, rely on faster and smoother languages. Fast languages are good at running many things, but not necessarily running things safer. Though from what I know C++ is still a really good security(or generic coding-related thing) choice because as you said: it's the best mediator between user-friendliness and speed(because slow is fine for security stuff but you don't want it TOO slow obviously).

replies.author: PLMA 1
replies.text:
In c++, "Enter your name" is a literal string. Basically anything between those 2 double quotes appears as it is when we run the program, now your mistake here is, the 
 means newline or endl(another name of newline) so it means that that's where the code line ends, so if you put it at the start of your literal string, the compiler will be confused because where your literal string starts is where you tell it that it ends, so now if you understood, you are going to put the 
 and the end of your literal string, but as you already put the endl next to your literal string, you're just going to remove the 
 and then try to run it again.

topLevelComment.author: Pasindu Jayasekara
topLevelComment.text:
Why is planning important before Coding?

Planning is important for any large project of any kind. For the parts that have to be communicated and agreed upon with other people, a document of some sort is probably the best answer. It isn’t necessary that it is ever printed on paper.

For some planning, white boards work just fine, but I’ve gotten in the habit of pulling out my phone and getting a picture of the final result of any white board planning sessions. In a day or two, I will have forgotten some of the details. In a week, I’ll remember some piece of it completely different from what was discussed.

Planning helps you to do three things. First, you determine what decisions need to be made. Second, you consider the options. Third, you consider the impact that the various choices have on each other.

Basically, now I'm coding with C++ and i wanted to program a OOP system. I stucked when I code without a plan/diagram and then I draw a simple diagram then coding was getting easier.

This is how I developed amazing OOP and file handling travel management system with C++: https://youtu.be/viSEf6o0ibs
I hope this article and video will help to you guys!!

topLevelComment.author: Remy Lebeau
topLevelComment.text: The "Building a Guessing Game" tutorial has a flaw - the 'guess' variable is uninitialized when the 'while' loop tries to evaluate it, so the code has UNDEFINED BEHAVIOR.  The 'guess' variable needs to be explicitly initialized to a value other than 7 so the 'while' loop will run correctly.  Otherwise, the code should be modified to use a 'do..while' loop instead.

topLevelComment.text: For the calculator I made a version where the user inputs something like 10+5, and the program automatically identifies the operation and slices the input into parts to do it. Had an absolute blast making it :D

replies.author: twoblocksdown
replies.text: @Mazen Braika I used the .find function to search for the position of +, -, * and / from the input (as a string). If the program cannot find one it simply returns the position as -1. So I take the only position value that's > 0, and use it to slice the input string into three pieces (number 1, operation mark and number 2).

topLevelComment.author: Sharkyn
topLevelComment.text:
Idk if someone pointed it out in the comments, just will leave this here, 'cause why not :)

1:53:54 Mike writes { ...else if(num2 >= num1 && num2 >= num3)... }, we can just throw away condition with >=num1. The reason is: we already in the first statement looked if num1 is the biggest. If it's not, then we go to this step, right? So we don't need to compare 1 and 2, we have done it before. On that point num1 is not the biggest (or not one of the biggest) and is left sitting in the corner - _-)/

topLevelComment.author: christian aussourd
topLevelComment.text:
I worked as a computer scientist in the physics field for years using a mixed language parallel programming technique (C & Fortran & MPI) to get the best of both world and I do confess it works fairly well.
Currently retired, I go on and besides this I want to explore new programming techniques I had few or no time to learn when I was active due to too close milestones.
Learning C++ from scratch from bulky books is not that easy so I tried numerous tutorials. Some of them were good some not. Eventually, I found the best ever : yours.
It fulfills all my expectations. 
Explanations are crystal clear and, moreover, they highlight the philosophy of C++. 
You deserve to become a professor if it is not the case yet. 
Thank you very much.

topLevelComment.author: Evgeny Tolmachev
topLevelComment.text: How to declare an array in class(spend hours with no success)? For example: class Speaker{ int freq_range[2];}; Speaker super_hifi; super_hifi.freq_range = {45,28000};  it doesn't work =(((

replies.author: K G.
replies.text:
@Evgeny Tolmachev *well not necessarily*

Yes, necessarily. The array must be initialized once and only once. That happens when the object is constructed (in the body of the class, or the constructor member initializer). If you want to modify the array after initialization, you cannot use the list initialization syntax with the {} (curly braces). You must access the individual element and set it equal to what you want it to be, such as array[7] = 4; see here for more details:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10694689/how-to-initialize-an-array-in-c-objects

If you want to pass an array as an argument, you can simply make the function accept a pointer to that array.

replies.author: Evgeny Tolmachev
replies.text:
@K G. well, not necessarily
but ok, if so, how do I pass an array as argument?

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: You need to use a constructor to initialize the array.

topLevelComment.author: Mega Byte
topLevelComment.text:
Here's some basic things you might wanna know:

To print ANY text you will need to use *cout << "TEXT HERE" << endl;*

The Data Types are:

string (Just to store some plain text)
char (Only used to store ONE Character)
int (Can only store whole numbers)
double (Can store more numbers than int AND can also be used for precise numbers like a decimal)
float (Can be used to make decimals)
bool (Bascially it's true or false, this isn't important if you haven't learned about if and else statements yet.)

topLevelComment.author: ytpSG
topLevelComment.text: Is there an advantage from endl over \n or why are you using it instead?

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: I would prefer '\n' to std::endl in most cases. The reason being std::endl not only outputs a newline, but it also flushes the stream's internal buffer. If you are doing this thousands of times in, say, a loop, this could be a performance bottleneck.

topLevelComment.author: Dave Poo
topLevelComment.text: WARNING: Memory management isn't covered in this video. I know it's one of those topics that scares off new C & C++ programmers, but unfortunately it's something you need to know . If you've watched this whole thing then you don't know the difference between stack & heap memory and therefore you don't know about the lifetimes of the stuff you are creating in memory. You won't be able to write successful C++ programs without knowing this. "Sams Teach Yourself C++ in 24 Hours" has a chapter on Memory management and covers the stack and heap and things like dangling pointers. I would recommend reading that or something like it otherwise you won't know what you are doing.

replies.author: 97epicman
replies.text:
@Allen Goodwin Whenever people say something along the lines of "don't learn anything that you don't need to learn" I always disagree. Knowing how to write drivers might come in handy even if you're not writing drivers; the deep knowledge of how drivers work and all the transferable skills that come with that could be priceless to you. Learning only what you need to has the potential to make you a stale, uncreative developer, and that's why so many companies pay extra for staff that are passionate and learning a variety of things outside their specific area.

Of course, you should always prioritise. But learning for the sake of learning is an incredibly valuable way to spend your time.

topLevelComment.author: Disha Jain
topLevelComment.text: what is the significance of putting an integer, at 46:14?

replies.author: Swift
replies.text: It is the index you want to start looking for the string you entered in the first position in the brackets, I assume you are familiar with index. Find function looks for the string you enter in the first position of the parenthesis, example: string Phrase = "Hello World"; then cout << phrase.find("World" ---> I am looking for the string "World" in our variable called Phrase, then you as you asked why you put an integer, so something like this: phrase.find("World", 0 ---> this means we start at the index of [0] which means we want to start at the beginning of the string (since this isn't an array - this means it will go through each individual letter), if I tell the index to start looking at to be 3, it would start at the fourth letter. INDEX works in this format: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5...….]. Hopefully this answers your question and have a great day.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
Wdym?
 
The overloaded << operator returns an std::ostream reference, so you can do chaining.
  
    stream << first << second << '\n';
 
But if you have only one variable to output, you can just use it once:
  
    stream << var; // optionally add << '\n' to end the line.

topLevelComment.text: What are the issues I will run into while 'using namespace std'?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
- Pollutes the global namespace. 
  - Could cause name clashes.
 
- Makes it unclear where everything is from, especially when using third-party libraries.
  
Namespaces were added to C++ in order to prevent these things. They're a pretty important C++ feature that you gotta get used to as you'll be using it a lot, so there's no point in trying to get around them.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
First, you need to get all of the basics of modern C++ down. For that, I would recommend the website learncpp.
  
When you're done with that, it's just a matter of how you want to make games. If you want to use a game engine, Unreal Engine is a pretty popular one. It's really powerful, and uses C++ for its scripts.
  
If you want to make games from scratch, you have far more options. I would suggest you start small, and pick up a graphics library that handles everything for you. The industry standard library for simple graphics is SDL2. It handles things like window creation, 2D graphics rendering, keyboard and mouse, controller, and touch support, basic audio, basic logging, and much more. The core SDL library provides mostly just the bare essentials, but there are a few sub-libraries that extend its functionally. There's SDL_image for loading images from a variety of different file types, SDL_mixer for enhanced audio support, SDL_ttf for True Type Font support, and SDL_net for networking support. The nice thing about this is that if you don't like how SDL handles one thing, you can just swap that sub-library with another. Even some AAA games use SDL, most notably Valve. It's written in C, as most graphics libraries are, but has direct support for C++, so you'll have to get used to doing things the data ordinated way. Since you have to manage dynamic memory manually in C, you have to remember to wrap SDL types that require manual memory management in smart pointers as avoidable manual memory management is frowned upon in modern C++ (e.g. use std::unique_ptr<SDL_Window, decltype(&SDL_DestroyWindow)> instead of a plain SDL_Window *, so you wouldn't have to call SDL_DestroyWindow yourself). It's cross-platform, so you can easily port your game to different OSs and mobile.

SDL: https://libsdl.org
Docs: https://wiki.libsdl.org/APIByCategory
  
Another popular graphics library is SFML. It isn't as popular as SDL, and no AAA games use it, but it's frequently used by beginners. Unlike SDL, it comes as a single library, and is written in C++11. I've used both SDL and SFML, and I'm personally not a fan of SFML, but you can try both and see which one you prefer.
  
SFML: https://www.sfml-dev.org
Docs: https://www.sfml-dev.org/documentation/2.5.1/
  
Once you gain some experience in gamedev, you can move on to a graphics API that gives you complete control over the graphics and the GPU. A highly popular graphics API is OpenGL. It's cross-platform, and is probably the easiest to learn. It's only a graphics API, so you'll need to get a separate library for window creation, and even for loading the OpenGL functions and other symbols. Both SDL and SFML support OpenGL, so you can pair it with one of them if you'd like. You could also go with a platform-specific graphics API, like DirectX, which is only available on Windows.

topLevelComment.author: GamingInSlowMotion
topLevelComment.text:
When he talks about pointers, is kind of weird. Pointers are just variables that are only ment to hold memory addresses and can be dereferenced(meaning you can the the values stores in that address).
It has to be the same type as the value stored in the address.

replies.author: GamingInSlowMotion
replies.text: Also now C++ has smart pointers and are very poweful.

replies.author: GamingInSlowMotion
replies.text:
In my career, I’ve seen pointers very useful to avoid the common way of replacing values (memory copy, paste, and modify, copy, paste )

Language C way was using the & as parameter for functions but it was only limited to that. With pointers you can use anywhere in scope.

Edit: pointers are very useful for own type pointers(data types created by you ie. Classes, structures,  or even arrays etc). 

Which stores big data and it avoids copy pasting and just changes values directly and is very good performance.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
If you’re referring to raw arrays, then you’re right, there’s no reason to use raw arrays over STL containers. In fact, you should actually avoid using raw arrays, unless you’re implementing your own data structure, or something like that.
 
But if you’re referring to std::array, then usually it’s best to use std::array over std::vector, if you know the size at compile-time

replies.text: @Iain Smith Many YouTube tutorials aren’t that great tbh, but the Cherno has a really good C++ series: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlrATfBNZ98dudnM48yfGUldqGD0S4FFb It doesn’t cover everything you can learn at learncpp though, and he doesn’t like to follow some of the best practices (like preferring { } for initialization over ( ) and =, not using new/delete, etc), but it’s still a good series.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: You can learn the rest of the basics of C++ at learncpp.com. Once you’re done with that, it’s just a matter of practice. Get familiar with the standard library, and then maybe start working on some projects using external libraries, as the standard library provides only a little more than just bare essentials. en.cppreference.com is a good website to use as reference, and you can learn about some of the best C++ practices using the official C++ core guidelines: https://github.com/isocpp/CppCoreGuidelines/blob/master/CppCoreGuidelines.md

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: @ً No, include <string> instead, it contains the std::getline declaration. <string.h> is from the C standard library, and no C headers ending with a .h should ever be used in C++ (if you need to use the C standard library, use the C++ized versions, which don’t end with a .h, and always begin with a c. e.g. <cstdio>, <cstdlib>, <cstring>. Just remember to prefix all symbols used from those headers with std::, as the global versions aren’t required to be included by the standard, so your code might not work on all compilers).

topLevelComment.author: Yasmin Montesino
topLevelComment.text: why dont we just use double all the time instead of int?

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: Floating point data types use special floating point instructions and are more expensive

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: One big reason for not always using doubles is to state your intent more clearly. If it logically makes no sense for a number to be a decimal, why use double? A double is also bigger than an int or a float, and can also be slower. If you just need to store an integer, use one of the int types. If you need to store a decimal number, use a float, or if you need extra precision, use a double or a long double.

topLevelComment.author: Iman
topLevelComment.text: Hello guys. what's the difference between cin.getline(string name) and getline(cin,string name)? I've seen several code like this and I don't know the difference.

replies.author: Iman
replies.text: @Artem Katerynych  This kind of question can stop me , thank you sir for your answer.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: According to cppreference ( https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/basic_istream/getline ), std::basic_istream<CharT,Traits>::getline takes in a const char pointer, while std::getline takes in an std::basic_string reference. So if you’re using const char *, use std::cin.getline, and if you’re using an std::string, use std::getline.

topLevelComment.author: Wunkie2

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
- You misspelled characterAge
 
- There is no need to declare the variable on one line, but give it a value on the next line. Just give it a value immediately.
 
e.g.
 
    int characterAge{17};
  
- Prefer uniform initialization, with { }, over other forms of initialization, like = or ( ), as uniform initialization is much safer and avoids the most vexing parse.
 
- Don’t do using namespace std as it is widely considered to be bad practice.
 
- Always include the header files you need; don’t rely on other header files including the files you need (unless the entire purpose of the header file is to include all the most commonly used files), as your code can break if the includes change in the included files, and your code might not compile on some compilers. Since you’re using std::string, you need to include <string>.
 
- If you don’t need the functionally that std::string provides, use std::string_view, from <string_view>, instead, as it is much faster since it doesn’t dynamically allocate any memory. std::string_view is pretty much a replacement for C’s const char *. Since you’re only viewing the contents of the string, std::string_view is perfect for you. Because std::string_view was added in C++17, you’ll need to make sure you’re compiling the project as C++17.
 
- if you just want to end the line, use `\n`. If you want to end the line and flush the stream, use std::endl.
 
- If a variable is not supposed to or is not going to change, and can be evaluated at compile time, make it a constexpr. If it can’t be evaluated at compile time, make it const.

topLevelComment.text: how to save c++ as exe file?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: If you compiled your program, you already have an .exe file. Check your output directory. On Visual Studio, it’s <ProjectDir>/bin/<Configuration>/. For instance, if your program is finished, you probably compiled it in the “release” configuration, rather than “debug,” (if you haven’t, you should) so you’ll find it in <ProjectDir>/bin/Release/. Keep in mind that if you previously relied on the IDE keeping the program open even after it finished its execution, it won’t be doing this anymore when you run the .exe file manually. Since it is (I assume) a console application, you can just run it through the command line, like you would run any other console program. Alternatively, you can just have the program await input once it’s done. You can do this by writing std::cin.get() before the return statement in main. Then, the program will remain running even after it reaches the end of main, until you hit <Enter>.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: You shouldn’t do using namespace std, it’s bad practice. And if you just want to end the line, use ‘\n’. If you want to end the line and flush the stream, use std::endl. Also, prefer uniform initialization, with { }, over other forms of initialization, like copy initialization, with =, or ( ) initialization. Lastly, you should maybe prefer the pre-increment operator (++x), over post increment (x++), as the latter will create a copy of the variable, as it increments the variable, but returns the original value, unlike the former, which increments the variable and returns the new value. The copy isn’t a big deal when using fundamental types, but for bigger types, it could be an unnecessary loss of performance. Also, it kinda makes your intention more clear, as you just want to increment the variable, not caring for its original value.

hi sir I know that it s not good to write like this comment but I watched your video about C++ and even though I couldn't do my exercise so if you please help me in that I will be so glad or even giving me an idea 
exercise(On demande la réalisation d’une classe « Number » permettant de gérer des nombres entiers 
et réels. La classe contient une seule propriété « value » de type double et fournit les constructeurs et 
services suivants : 
- Number() 
- Number(int value) 
- Number(double value) 
- Number(char *value) : permettant d’extraire la valeur réelle depuis une chaîne si elle contient 
bien une valeur réelle. Si la chaîne ne contient que des 0 et des 1, elle est alors considérée une 
chaîne binaire ; sa valeur décimale sera ainsi calculée et stockée dans la propriété « value » 
- La méthode setValue surchargée pour les 3 types de données supportés par les constructeurs. 
- Trois méthodes de récupération de la valeur avec les 3 formats possibles : int, double et 
binaire. 
- Une méthode de récupération de la valeur sous forme d’une chaîne de caractères avec le 
format précisé en paramètres : Nombre de caractères et nombre de chiffres après la virgule. 
- Une méthode de génération aléatoire de la valeur. 
- Surcharger les opérateurs ++, --, += et -=) thank you so much for all your courses and I really appreciate it😊😊

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
1. You never included <string>. Always include the header files you need; don’t try to rely on other included header files including the files you need.
 
2. Don’t write using namespace std, it is widely considered to be bad practice.
 
3. You misspelled length.
 
4. Avoid copy initialization (initializing with the assignment operator) and ( ) initialization. Instead, prefer uniform initialization, with { }, when possible.

topLevelComment.author: Dude
topLevelComment.text:
Just to point something out, if you use double instead of float even when you don't need double, you are being careless with memory management, which is crucial with c++.
To conclude, don't use double unless you need it. Use float instead, as it uses less memory.

replies.author: diliup gabadamudalige
replies.text: I was just gonna ask what about float and thI saw your statement here. This is one problem with most Youtube tutorials. A float uses 32 bits whereas a double uses 64 bit and hence the name. So there is a clear distinction to where which should be used.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: Just like every other fundamental type, a bool is just an integer. So if you want to input it using std::cin, you can either just get a 0 (false) or a 1 (true, can also be any value), or get a string and check if it’s “true” or “false” (or something similar). If you get it as a string, you might want to convert it to all-lowercase before you check it.

topLevelComment.author: NEW PLAYER

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: You need to include <string>. Also, that’s not how you properly initialize members in C++. You need to use a constructor initializer list (https://www.learncpp.com/cpp-tutorial/8-5a-constructor-member-initializer-lists/). Also, by defining all the functions inside the actual class definition, you are implicitly making all those functions inline, which you shouldn’t do (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/inline/). Strings are also an expensive object to copy, so do not pass them by value. Instead, either pass them by const reference, or even better, use string_view from <string_view> (make sure you’re compiling with C++17). And lastly, don’t do using namespace std, it is widely considered to be bad practice. Just prefix everything from the standard library with std::.

topLevelComment.author: Andrei Tscm
topLevelComment.text: For anyone who's got string error (because of using visual studio for example, or the program can't just find the string.h header file) you should include string.h in the top of the cpp file like that: #include "string.h"  (there are quotes "" because it can include all header files that can be outside of the project too while <> can only include headers inside the project)

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: No no, it should be <string>. string.h is from the C standard library and should *never* be used in C++. If you did need to use the C string header, use <cstring>. All C++ header files (and C++ized C header files) do not end with .h, and the C files that do have .h shouldn’t be used, they’re there just for compatibility reasons.

replies.author: Andrei Tscm
replies.text: and of course don't forget when you create a string variable to create it like that: std::string example = "hello youtube";

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: @chella ack Maybe, but not in all cases. Like I already said, if you have a function that just uses one library, it’s fine to do using namespace inside that function.  It’s also fine to do it if you’re using something from a namespace with a long name, but in that case you should consider exposing just the symbols you need by doing “using <symbol from namespace>;” However, defaulting to “using namespace” every time is a terrible idea.

topLevelComment.author: owen5819
topLevelComment.text: Just beginning this. Can anyone suggest a "best" replacement for CodeBlocks? (By "best," I mean easiest to set up and use while providing adequate facilities, not the most powerful.) Using CodeBlocks on my Windows machine, but it's no longer available for the current revision of Mac OS, which runs my laptop. Wondering about Visual Studio Code, but my immediate purpose is to build add-ons for some software, and other users have reported that code from Visual Studio itself tends not to work. Thanks.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: For Windows, Visual Studio 2019 is the way to go. It’s a really powerful IDE, and it comes ready with its own compiler, MSVC. It supports a few different languages too, and setting it up is really easy. It’s only available on windows though (VS for Mac only supports C# last I checked), for macOS you should take a look at xCode. You can also go with a code editor instead of an IDE, but you’ll have to get several add-ons to get all of the features that IDEs offer. There’s plenty to choose from, the most popular ones are VS Code, Atom, Vim, and Sublime Text.

replies.author: Inventa Gaming
replies.text: Visual Studio Code and Visual Studio 2019 are both great replacements for CodeBlocks, Although their file size are massive, if your planning to work with multiple languages in the future, those two are the best to go. And with a quick google search, you'll have a project up and running. If you were looking for another though, I would google or watch another youtube video.

topLevelComment.author: ipsen ipsen
topLevelComment.text: this tutorial is great, thanks a bunch. i do have one question, which i am really curious about. when you in the tutorial write cout or endl; i however have to write std::cout or std::endl; why the difference? i dont mind it, but i dont understand how one doesnt have to write it, and another does??

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: Everything in the standard library is defined inside the std namespace. Therefore, you must prefix all types and functions from the standard library with std::. You can bypass this by writing `using namespace std`, but doing so is discouraged and should probably be avoided.

replies.author: Warren Hawker
replies.text: @eylon951 repetition repetition repetition. Also, what has helped me following this course is to try out things before he gives you the solution. For example, I'm currently on the "Guessing Game" section, but instead of just sitting there watching him code it all, as soon as he gave the outline of what he wanted to do, I paused the video and tried to do it myself using the techniques I had learned in earlier sections. This approach is far more effective because it gets you to really think it through and experiment a little rather than being told everything. Then once you figure it out, unpause the video and confirm the solution.

topLevelComment.author: roshiron 18
topLevelComment.text: Thank you so much. You made all the BS in my textbook understandable. One thing that wasn't clear though is... WHY use pointers? They seem like a middleman. Why not just use the variables that they reference?

replies.author: roshiron 18
replies.text: @Artem Katerynych Thank you for the informative response Artem!

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
You use a pointer when you need to store a memory address.
 
One reason you may need to do that is when you dynamically allocate memory. When you allocate memory using new, you need to store the memory address it returns in a pointer. However, for dynamic memory allocation you should avoid using new and instead use a smart pointer like std::unique_ptr or std::shared_ptr.
 
Another use for pointers is optional function parameters. If you want a parameter to be optional, you can just take it in as a pointer, then check if it’s nullptr or not. If it is, you can just ignore it. For optional variables, you should actually use std::optional. However, it does not allow you to store references, so if you do not want to copy the data, you need to pass it as a pointer.
 
Pointers are also used for creating polymorphic variables. You can make a base class and have some sub-classes inherit from it. Then, you can create a pointer to a base class and set it to a memory address of any of the sub-classes. You can actually do this with references, but often you’d need to dynamically allocate the memory for the objects, and in that case you’d need to use a pointer.

One thing you can do with a pointer that you cannot do with a reference is reassign them. Although they behave sort of similar, don’t think of references as pointers with nicer syntax. When you create a reference, it pretty much _becomes_ the variable itself, and you cannot reassign it. A pointer is just a memory address, and therefore you can give it a different memory address at any point.
 
You’ll also be using pointers a lot if you’re working with a C library. Since C is backwards compatible with C++, you’ll probably end up using a C library at some point. Since C does not have references, pointers will be used for a lot of things. Other than things C has that I already mentioned, like dynamic memory allocation and optional parameters, pointers in C can be used to avoid copying data. Just like you’d pass a variable by reference to avoid copying it in C++, you’d need to pass the variable by a pointer. Pointers in C can also be used to write data to a specific memory address. At some point, you might need to call a function that is supposed to give you some data, but instead of returning said data, it instead expects a pointer. The function simply just dereferences the pointer and writes the data there. Since you can only return one variable, this is sometimes done when the function needs to give you multiple variables.

topLevelComment.author: AstroTibs
topLevelComment.text:
The description of the **break** statement in the switch section isn't quite correct.
Without "break;" the code will continue downward, executing each successive case whether or not the switch value (dayNum) equals those case statements. The "break;" simply prevents the switch from continuing this way.

Don't think of "case: 3" as meaning: "execute this code if the switch is equal to 3"; think of it more as: "execute all the switch code, _starting here_.

So a switch is even more versatile than a multi-condition if statement.

topLevelComment.author: bala rao
topLevelComment.text: What we should do in float

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: What? Are you asking when you should use float? Typically, you’d use double to store floating-point numbers. It’s the default data type for storing decimal numbers. Floats are half the size of doubles, therefore they offer less precision. They also might be a little faster than doubles. So you should use floats when you want to save some memory, and need the small potential performance gain.

topLevelComment.author: TheBadassTonberry
topLevelComment.text:
Using both cin and getline() doesn't seem to work for me.
I can enter a number with cin just fine, but as soon as i press enter, the program basically skips the next part.

help?

[EDIT]
So apparently the problem is that if you use cin first, it will leave a newline in the buffer, which will stay and cause getline() to skip input.
You can fix this by using cin.ignore(), but I don't know how that exactly works. The easier temporary solution is to just use getline() before cin.

replies.author: TheBadassTonberry
replies.text:
@Shital Kiran Nope, I used cin correctly.
I googled the problem and it is exactly as I described in [EDIT]. It is impossible to use cin before getline() without cin.ignore() or clearing the buffer in any other way, or getline() will be skipped.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: In C++, they’re called functions. Functions that are not part of a class are called free functions, and functions that are members of a class or a struct are called member functions. Member functions are also sometimes called methods by people who come from a different language.

topLevelComment.author: Frits van Doorn
topLevelComment.text: In the while part he uses guess without initialisation. What is the value of guess the first time?

replies.author: Frits van Doorn
replies.text: @Artem Katerynych thank you

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: That is actually a big mistake, you should never use a variable without initializing it. When you declare a variable like that, you allocate the memory for it but a value is never set for it. If you try to read its value, you’ll just get whatever data was previously stored in that memory block. Usually it will be just a bunch of random numbers. Using an uninitialized variable actually results in undefined behaviour, so on some systems it may still work, but on some your program might just crash. Since you need to use guess, you need to give it a value, like 0 or maybe -1 to denote that it has no real value.

topLevelComment.author: invalide_account
topLevelComment.text: for 'building a better calculator' 1:55:58 - when the user inputs an invalid operator, console message is "Invalid operator", as planned, and then has a weird string of numbers with some massive or tiny exponent value, depending on what you typed as the invalid operator. i'm guessing this is because cout << result; is still getting called, even after we've cycled through the else statement, so how do you stop it from getting called in the instance of an invalid operator?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: Just make sure that the statement never gets executed. There are many ways to do that. You can simply return out of the function if the operator is invalid. You can also create a boolean, and set it to a certain value if the operator is incorrect, then before calling the output statement test the boolean.

topLevelComment.author: Sadaf Ali
topLevelComment.text: why did you write public in class?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: To declare its members as public. There are 3 visibility specifiers in C++, public, protected, and private. Public members can be accessed from outside the class from anywhere. Protected members can only be accessed by the class defining them, its subclasses, and its friends. Private members can only be accessed by the class defining them and its friends.

topLevelComment.author: Jordy Taylor
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks, Mike for this awesome tutorial! I took C++ in 8 weeks in my Spring semester earlier this year, and your 4 hour video covered everything we learned, plus some! Of course, we had to do examples, practice problems, projects, and exams in class, but you did a good job refreshing my memory on something I practiced almost 6 months ago.  Cheers dude!

For the YouTube community, 
Does anyone have any recommendations for places (or more YouTube videos) where I can find practice problems for beginner C++ programming? I'm on a mission to keep waking up every morning to practice coding for an hour first thing before I do anything else, and again for an hour before I go to bed.  I am a Mechatronics student right now, so this would be ideal to keep sharpening my skills.  Thanks for any feedback!

I saw it at once and it was an excellent lesson. But you need and a second part to teach people about opening files (text and binary and doing file operations like reading directories or deleting files), lists, linked lists, graphics(Not console window only), more advanced input functions(Keyboard scan codes), and more game-related stuff(Some Game Library and graphic things about colors and sprites).
And suggest one nice game library among all of these (SDL, SFML, ALLEGRO), attempting to entering in 2D and 3D game programming.

replies.author: TheBadassTonberry
replies.text:
@Aust From what I've seen, it's not that bad.
You don't NEED your own engine, however you WILL need to set up a game loop, as well as doing a lot of things that a engine usually handles by yourself, such as collision detection, physics, etc, and if you use 3D models, set up the rendering pipeline (from what I've seen regarding DirectX/Direct3D),  and likely build a model loader
However, it can be done, just look at Minecraft Bedrock Edition or any homebrew GB Advance game (usually ROMs).
Hell, (early?) Pokémon games were written entirely in Assembly, so why would C++ NOT work?

Speaking of DirectX: Direct3D files (.x) are literally just a list of vertex coordinates when opened in any texteditor.

topLevelComment.author: Nishant Deo
topLevelComment.text: But whats the use of pointers

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
There are many uses of pointers in C++.
  
You can use pointers for dynamic memory allocation. When you allocate memory on the free-store/heap, you will need to store that memory address in a pointer so that you could access that memory. For this, you should use a smart pointer, like std::unique_ptr.
  
You can also use pointers for polymorphism. You can create a base class and have different subclasses inherit from it. Then you can create some instances of those subclasses and store all of them as a base class pointer. You can also use references for this, but not when you need them to be allocated on the free-store/heap.
  
Pointers can be used for optional function parameters. You can just pass a variable to a function as a pointer, then check if it points to a valid memory address. If it’s nullptr, the function can just ignore it. You should probably use std::optional for this though.
  
Pointers are sometimes used to write data to a specific memory address. You can pass a pointer to a function and then it can write some data at that memory address. This is sometimes done when you need your function to return something, but also provide some additional information. However, you should probably use references for this.
 
Pointers are also used with raw arrays. Raw arrays are just pointers to sequential data. If you can, you should avoid using raw arrays and just use an STL container instead, like std::array or std::vector.

topLevelComment.author: BlackDuke
topLevelComment.text: If anyone is getting an error when trying to compile. For me, the problem was it was looking for the compiler in "Program Files (x86)" but it was installed in "Program Files". To change this select "Settings" from the menu bar, then "Compiler...", select "Toolchain executables" and then "Auto-detect", it should now find the correct path. If it doesn't find the correct path, manually change it to "C:\Program Files\CodeBlocks\MiniGW"

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
Song Aftaab This happens because your program reaches the end of its execution. When you run it through your IDE, your IDE keeps the console window open even after your program closes. 
 
In order to keep your program running, you need to stop it from returning out of main function until you want it to close. The easiest way to do this would be to have it wait for input before the program closes. To do this, just call std::cin.get() at the button of your main function (before your return statement, if you have one).
 
Also, instead of using CodeBlocks, I suggest you get a better IDE, like Visual Studio 2019 or CLion.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: The main function returns an int, which is the exit code. By returning 0, you are saying that the execution of the program went fine. Returning 1 or a different number means that some error occurred. If you do not give a return statement in the main function, the compiler will implicitly add one for you.

topLevelComment.author: Skrskrskr r
topLevelComment.text: Can someone explain ehy would i need pointers?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
There are many uses of pointers.
 
One use of pointers is for polymorphism. You can create a base class and have different classes inherit from it. Then, you can create a pointer to the base class but point it to an instance of a sub-class. This can also be achieved with references.
 
Another popular use of pointers is free-store/heap allocation. If you need to allocate some memory dynamically rather than on the stack, you need to use a pointer to access that memory.
 
Pointers can also be used to avoid copying data. Instead of passing a variable by value, you can instead just pass the memory address of that variable. The function can then dereference it and access the data. However, it would be much easier to just use references for this.
 
You can also use pointers for optional function parameters. If you pass a pointer to a function, the function can check if it is pointing a valid memory address or not. If the pointer is nullptr, it can just ignore it. However, the same can be done better with std::optional.
 
Pointers are also used with raw arrays, since raw arrays are just pointers to sequential data. Most of the time, you should just avoid raw arrays and use an STL container instead, like std::vector or std::array.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
This is because you never ended the line. After every console output, you probably want to end the line so that all future input will go onto a separate line. You can do this by putting “\n” at the end of your output. 
 
E.g.
 
     std::cout << “Enter your name:\n”

You can also use std::endl, but this ends the line and flushes the stream. If you don’t want to flush the stream, just use “\n”.

topLevelComment.author: Shillslayer McHammer
topLevelComment.text: if x = c++, does c = x-- ?

replies.author: Shillslayer McHammer
replies.text:
​@Artem Katerynych Oh I understand the concepts just fine :) ....  I was merely mixing up some pseudocode/algebra with incrementals for word play with C and C++ language names. 
i.e 
x = c++ (x = c+1) .... which solves algebraically to c = x-1 (c = x--) 
:)
Less funny when explained I suppose lol

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
In the first one you are setting x to c, and in the second one you are setting c to x. I think you mean to compare them, and for that you use ==. If x == c++ then c != x— because you are post-incrementing c and x. 
 
Let’s say that c is set to the value of 1. When you do x = c++, you post-increment c, which means that it returns the original value first, then increments it. Now x is 1 and c is 2. If you do c == x—, it will evaluate to false, then decrease x by 1.

Now c is 2 and x is 0.
 
Unless you need the original value first, always pre-increment because post-incrementation gives you a copy of the original value first. For fundamental types it doesn’t make much difference, but if you do this with a larger object it could be slow.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: Instead of using std::getline, use the >> operator with std::cin. Also, do not do using namespace std as it can cause name collisions. If you want to end the line, use “\n”. If you want to end the line and flush the stream, use std::endl.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
Pranay Reddy What do you mean by how to link it to the IDE and try Visual Studio? Visual Studio is a completely different IDE. The community edition is completely free, so go download it and give it a try. If for some reason you want to stick to CodeBlocks (I recommend that you don’t), you just go to the compiler settings and provide it the path to your installed compiler. You can also make it just look for any installed compilers. 

CodeBlocks should be able to auto-detect all your installed compilers. When you open it for the first time, it gives you a list of all the available compilers, you just need to pick one and it should work fine.

If you don’t have a compiler installed, download one. You can also get the CodeBlocks bundle that comes with the MinGW compiler. When you install it, just select MinGW from the list of compilers.
 
Visual Studio comes with its own compiler, MSVC. When you install Visual Studio, everything will already be setup for you, so you don’t have to do anything. If you want to use a different compiler, you can do that pretty easily by going into your project settings.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
No, the find function does not return a memory address. The find function finds the position of a certain character. The first argument is what character to find, and the second argument is where to start looking. Because you started looking at index 3, the find function never finds the character.
 
Also, for finding a single character you should pass a character rather than a string.

topLevelComment.text: 53:00 Those are postfix operators, but there are also prefix operators, where a postfix operator example is "wnum++", a prefix operator example is "++wnum". Postfix uses the value before incrementing it, whereas prefix increments the value before using it.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
What do you mean you used namespace std? If you put using namespace std; (which you really should not be doing as it can cause name collisions) before the main function, you should be able to access endl, just make sure you include <iostream>.
 
If you didn’t do using namespace std;, you have to prefix everything defined in the std namespace with std::, so you’d have to do std::endl.

replies.text: @Artem Katerynych my mistake, I just assumed you could use sizeof()

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: SerBallister Since raw arrays decay into a pointer when passed into a function, specifying the size doesn’t really matter.

replies.author: SerBallister
replies.text: @Artem Katerynych Good points, although your example function of  [] type (pointer) argument could be replaced with the size, e.g.  void fun(int array[20]);    [] like you say, is not an array, it's a reference to a pointer

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
SerBallister I’ll give you some examples.
 
When you pass a raw array into a function, it decays into a plain raw pointer. Since pointers do not keep information such as the size, you need to pass the size as an additional parameter (using std::size_t or int). 
std::array can easily be passed to a function and it will retain all its data. For instance, you can get the size of the array by using the size() member function.
 
There is also no way to return a raw array, you will just be returning a pointer to a local variable if you created it in that scope. std::array on the other hand can be easily returned.
 
Optionally, you can have bounds checking with std::array. This will throw an exception if you try to access an element that does not exist in the array. With raw arrays, if you try to access something that isn’t part of that array, you will just be accessing memory that does not belong to you, and this will result in undefined behaviour.

You cannot easily copy or move raw arrays, but std::array can easily be copied or moved.
  
You can use an iterator with std::array. begin() will give you an iterator that starts at the beginning, and end() will give you the end of the array.
 
There are also a few other useful member functions that std::array has, such as front() and back().

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
You should start by learning C++. Learn the basics of the language, and get familiar with its standard library. Once you feel confident with C++, you can start learning how to make games. 
 
If you want to use a game engine, you can find an engine you like and learn how to use it. Unreal Engine is a very popular choice for C++. 
 
If you want to make games from scratch, you should start by learning how to use a graphics library. You should begin with a simple one that handles everything for you, like SDL2 or SFML. 
 
SDL2, short for Simple Direct Media-layer, is a cross-platform library that handles graphics, audio, input, and much more. It is written in C, but can easily be used in C++. SDL is very popular, and even some AAA games use SDL. The core SDL library handles the basic things, like graphics, input, basic audio support, etc. To extend its functionality, you can get other SDL sub-libraries that handle more specific things. There is SDL_image for loading images from a variety of different file types, SDL_mixer for enchanted audio support, SDL_ttf for font support, and SDL_net for networking support. This allows you to get only what you need, and if you don’t like how SDL handles one thing, you can just substitute it with a different library.

SFML stands for simple and fast multimedia library. It is similar to SDL, but it is written in C++. It is not as popular as SDL, but it is often used by beginners. Unlike SDL, everything in SFML comes in just one single library.

I’ve used both SFML and SDL, and personally I like SDL the best.

Once you gain some experience with game development, you can pick up a graphics API  that lets you do everything yourself. OpenGL is a very popular choice as it is cross-platform, and is probably one of the easiest to learn. Both SDL and SFML can be used with OpenGL. You can also learn how to use a platform specific graphics API, like DirectX which is only available on Windows.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
Squeecy 
There are multiple ways to setup a library. For serious projects, I prefer to download the source code, and compile the library myself. To do this, right click on your solution in the solution explorer, go to Add, and click New Project. From there, create an empty C++ project. Then, I like to click on the Show All Files button in solution explorer. This will let you see how the project actually looks on the drive, without all the fake folders. I usually make a folder called Source, and copy all the source files there. Then, right click on the project, and click properties. Make sure that the configuration is set to all configurations, and platform is set to all platforms. In the general tab, click Configuration Type, and change it from application to either static library or dynamic library. Next, right click on your main project, and go to Build Dependencies. Then, click Project Dependencies, and select your library project. Now you can compile your projects. If you chose to compile it as a dynamic library, go to the library project’s output and get the .dll file, then move it the your main project’s output dir.
 
To setup a library without the source code, you should create a folder in your project dir that will contain all your libraries. I usually call it Dependencies.
Make sure that you have created at least 1 .cpp file in your project. Then, right click on your project in the solution explorer and click properties. Make sure that your configuration is set to all configurations, and your platform is set to all platforms.
 
In the general tab, I usually change the output and intermediate dir, as the default ones aren’t very good. I wouldn’t give it local paths though, instead I’d start the path with $(ProjectDir), followed by the path name. You should also set the C++ standard to the latest one, which is currently C++17.
 
Then, click on the little arrow next to C/C++, and click general. From there, you can specify the include directories. Libraries usually have an include folder, and a lib folder. You want to link the include folder here. You probably shouldn’t give it a local path though, instead write $(SolutionDir)Dependencies\YOUR_LIB_NAME\include\
 
Then, click the arrow on next to Linker, and click general. Even if you’re dynamically linking a library, libraries typically still come with static .lib files. This is because the static library files import all the definitions from the dll files for you, so that you wouldn’t have to do that manually. All the actual code will be defined in the .dll files. You can provide the lib folder path by clicking Additional Library Directories. You can use the $(SolutionDir) macro here as well. Your library may have an x86 and an x64 version, so you may have to switch to the specific platform first by clicking on Platform, then selecting the one you need. Then, click Input, then click Additional Dependencies. Here you specify the .lib files that you want to use. Just write each file name that you want to use, with .lib at the end of each name.

Next, if you dynamically linked your libraries, compile your program, then go to the output dir. Once you’re there, move all the .dll files you need here.
 
To change your SDK, right click on your project in Solution Explorer, and click properties. In the general tab, click Windows SDK version. This will let you select from an SDK version from your installed SDKs. By default, it’s set to the highest version you have installed. You really shouldn’t change it unless you have a very good reason to do so.

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
What IDE/editor are you using? 
 
To use external code, you need to give the compiler the header file directories, and give the linker the binaries. On Windows, static libraries have a .lib extension, and dynamic libraries have a .dll extension. If you use dynamic linking, make sure that the .dll files are in the same directory as the executable.
 
To add an SDK, you have to find that option if your IDE/editor project settings.

topLevelComment.text: In the exponent Function part, why did he set 'int result' equal to 1? Does it always have to be 1?

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: Jonathan M. You’re welcome

replies.author: Jonathan M.
replies.text: @Artem Katerynych thank you!

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
He set it to 1 because that’s its starting value. In the next line he made a for loop that will multiply the result with baseNum. If he didn’t initialize it, and tried to multiply its value, it would try to access uninitialized memory, and this would result in a segfault.
 
Also, it can be simplified to result *= baseNum;

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text: structures only exist in C++ for backwards compatibility with C. They are identical to classes, except for the fact that by default, everything in a struct is public. Structs are typically used as POD types, and classes are used when you want to have member functions and much more.

C++ is just a good tutorial language because it covers both the object oriented side as well as pointers.

topLevelComment.author: The
topLevelComment.text:
"Code::Blocks is currently not the default application for C/C++ source files. Do you want to set it as default?"
What do i set it to?
"No, leave everything as it is"
"Yes, associate Code::Blocks with C/C++ file types"
"Yes, associate Code::Blocks with every supported type (Including projects from other IDEs)

replies.author: Artem Katerynych
replies.text:
It’s a pretty straight forward question lol. If you want to associate CodeBlocks with C and C++ file types, click yes. If you do this, whenever you try to open a C or C++ file, it will be opened with CodeBlocks. If you don’t want it to do that, click no.

And as someone else has said, don’t use CodeBlocks. Visual Studio is far better.

I’m getting some wonky outputs on the functions that use getline immediately after having the user input from the keyboard

replies.author: Noah Leveille
replies.text:
Nvm I figured it out 

If anyone comes across this comment in the future - trying using cin.ignore() before using getline since the program doesn’t know how to respond to white spaces so it just skips the first user input 

Hope this helps anyone to comes across this!

replies.author: K G.
replies.text:
@Yassine Bibi Yes, calculators use floating point to represent decimal. Not sure where this is falling apart for you.

Also, that's not necessarily true. Many calculators implement Euclidean division/remainder functions. Though the default is usually just typical division with the answer represented using floating point.

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: @Yassine Bibi That's because your calculator uses floating point division and not division on integers with a remainder.

replies.author: Yassine Bibi
replies.text: @K G. an euclidean divison is not what a calculator returns when you do 7/2 , that's what i meant and ye i am a mathematician

replies.author: K G.

I have watched all 4 hours of this course and it is awesome. To anyone asking themselves is it worth investing the time into this, the answer is YES.

I've learned it the hard way, by sitting here for 4 hours and watching this course to find out I had all these concepts already down from Java (which took me far more than 4 hours to understand, by just reading code and trying to figure it out on my own).


This was really beneficial tho to strengthen these concepts and really make them mine.

topLevelComment.author: Folk.Punk.Feathers
topLevelComment.text:
Just finished the section on nested for loops, and gotta say man, I've been taking this in chunks of 3-4 lessons since about 1430 today, and having gone into this with no experience WHATsoever its super rewarding to see this paying off! I hit a stumble here and there, but its to the point where I can fix said issue by MYSELF instead of looking at YOUR code. I know theres ppl in here joking about


"Ha ha corona"
or
"12 week class in 4 hours"


But in all true honesty, the fact that YOUR video is the one that came up when these people needed a ew hyperfixation to pass the time says something. 3 million vews with a roughly 0.01% dislike ratio is HUGE.


I gess what I'm trying to say is thanks adn great work. This is something that has interested me for a while now, and you explain it so well, and its hella rewarding to see it paying off!

topLevelComment.author: BruhMode
topLevelComment.text: How do you learn c++ completely so that you could make AI, use api, be able to use graphics or making video games with xyz axis, creating software with graphics and so on. I have many purposes for c++ but I'm trying to figure out how to know what to use when I do a project. That's my problem is knowing what to use and also learning the whole language. Your number game made a lot of sense also wanted to let you know that helped me alot.

replies.author: K G.
replies.text:
@BruhMode There is nobody that knows every single component out there and can be able to use it on demand. That's why programmers have manpages and documentation on how to use new libraries.

Figure out what you want to do: game design? Networking? Security? Crypto? AI? Then, once you have chosen what you want, research the libraries and APIs that implement those features. Simple.

replies.author: BruhMode
replies.text:

I'd like to just know everything and be able to use it on demand basically but from what you said that's pretty difficult.

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: You have to research what components you want specifically and learn them.

Hi! Can someone help me with my C++ homework? It's below:

Write a program that uses random number generations to create sentences.
The program should use four arrays of pointers to char called article,noun verb and preposition. The program should create a sentence by selecting a word at random from which array in the following order: article, noun, verb, preposition, article and noun. As each word is picked it should be concatenated to the previous word in a character array that is big enough to hold the entire sentence. The words should be separated by spaces. When the final sentence is output , it should start with a capital letter and end with a period. The program should generate 20 such sentences. The arrays should be filled as follows: The article array should contain the articles "the" , "a" , " one" , "some" and "any" ; the noun array should contain the nouns "boy", "girl" , " dog" ,  "town" and "car"; the verb array should contain the verbs "drove" , "jumped" , "ran", "walked " and "skipped "; the preposition array should contain the prepositions "to", "from" , "over", "under" and "on". topLevelComment.author: Alixander
topLevelComment.text:
At 2:23:37 
The program runs on one compiler but not on another
the other says that "guess;" is uninitialized
why?

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: The results will differ on different compilers. The compiler that says "guess is uninitialized" still runs the program, right? That means it is giving you a warning, not a compilation error. If it was an error the program would not run. If it is actually an error, then you must have the compiler set to a stricter mode which treats warnings as compile time errors. The reason you get that error/warning is because the guess variable was not given a default value, hence it is "uninitialized" and if you were to print its value out right now it would display garbage.

topLevelComment.author: Gurken Gerd
topLevelComment.text: I'm still learning c++ in first semester at college, but when you talk about pointers you nearly always meant references, no? The pointer is only the variable with the *, the reference is the variable with the &.

replies.author: K G.
replies.text:
No, I think you misunderstood what & means. It can mean multiple different things. 


When you do it like this: &variable, then you are taking the "address of" a variable. A pointer is a variable that stores an address. Think of it like this:
int -> stores integer
char -> stores character 
string -> stores a string of characters
pointer -> stores an address.


If pointer were named more appropriately to follow this convention, we would call the data type "addr" or something to symbolize it holds an address.


What a reference is is basically an alternate name for a variable. You can think of it this way, even though the internal implementation is similar to a pointer. For example, this is a reference variable:


int& my_reference = variable;


now you can use both my_reference and variable interchangeably. They are both the same variable, but now they have two different names. This is the basic premise.

replies.author: K G.
replies.text:
@CodeZinx "faster to type"
Congratulations, you saved half of a second of effort by writing a for loop instead of a while loop \s.

replies.author: CodeZinx
replies.text: He already mentioned that in 2:32:10

replies.author: CodeZinx
replies.text: Meant faster to type

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: There is no reason for a particular loop to be faster if they are identical logically. Most compilers will generate the same code. There is no such thing as a "for loop" or "while loop" during run time.

replies.text: Experienced programmers start at 0 because they are used to indexing semantics

Great stuff zooming in and out like that. Perfect when watching in the phone. Also good to not jump from one view to the other. Superb sound quality. You should hear the room size and not a close radio voice. You kept your information on a constant level and explained stuff in a perfect way without getting ahead of yourself like many other tutorials tend to do: like "that was simple so let's do something that's not". Congratulations and many thanks for the video and for keeping it add free. Hope there's more to come.

topLevelComment.text:
please help me with this work
there are three seating categories at an athletic stadium.For Baseball game,Class A seats cost $15.00 each, Class B seats cost $12.00 each and Class C seats cost $9.00. Create a C++ program that allows the user to enter the number of ticket sold for each class. the program should display income and revenue generated. if the user does not enter a numeric value the program should not display the calculations.

replies.author: W C
replies.text: Just do cin for each type of seats. Then do variable(num of seats) * price, and make that a variable, ex priceSeat1 = sumOfSeats * 15. For total do something like total = priceSeat1 + priceSeat2 + priceSeat3. Then cout all of them. Do an if to check if it is an int value.

topLevelComment.author: Josh Robbins Ditto305
topLevelComment.text:
Man.. this program really sacrifices accessibility and ease of use for a broader and more of a range of things to be able to do.
Like having to use "Bool" to be able to set things to true or false, but then having to use int for non decimal and double for decimal.
I've used programs that just do this for you.
Like you could set Numcount1 = 5 but then change that to Numcount1 = true and it would just change the variable in the code because it recognizes that you want to change it.
The only time it would be relevant is if you wanted to have Numcount1 be all of the above at the same time but then that would make it confusing to fix if something goes wrong so I don't see the point.

topLevelComment.author: Juan Miguez
topLevelComment.text: You definintely touched in a lot of good points, but there is a LOT of missing pieces of an awesome tutorial. First, missing the "struct" and how to properly handle exceptions. A good part of C++ programming is also interfacing with the OS and the multiple OSs that are out there. The total basics were not covered for example, some more data structures, date and time, basic input/output, namespaces, dynamic memory, etc. Furthermore if you actually say to someone that you are going to teach objects... well... it's only 20% accomplished. For example, multiple inheritance, polymorphism, abstraction, encapsulation, interfaces, etc. If you could please make an advanced class and cover more topics. On a very positive note, your voice is awesome for tutorials!

topLevelComment.author: cs
topLevelComment.text:
what is difference between void and return 
i used void function in return statement program  and i got same results 
i didnt get the actual difference between void and return

replies.author: Rynology
replies.text: If I understand your question correctly. You are asking what the difference between a Void Function and a function that returns a value? If so then the difference is simply that all functions, with the exception of void, must return a value. For example in the statement "int x = getx();" the value of x is whatever the returned value from the getx function is. Hope this helps!
