topLevelComment.author: Emmaus Rubio
topLevelComment.text: I have a question about pointers. What's the point of doing "*&gpa" on your example to get the actual value of the variable, where you can just put cout << gpa; to print the value?

replies.author: K G.
replies.text: He does that to show you that memory addresses can be dereferenced because they are just unnamed pointers. Obviously, in practice, you would just use cout << gpa; but he was just trying to make a point that you could just take the address of GPA degree dereference it using "*" and it would get you the value.

replies.text:
I'm guessing you're having trouble with using commands like cout and stuff and that's why the code won't run.
CodeBlocks includes this line "using namespace std;" at the start of a new file, and maybe that online site.
I think it like, adds "std::" automatically before commands like cout, allowing it to run.
Try it, add "using namespace std;" to the beginning of the file.

replies.author: Melkior Wiseman
replies.text:
If that's an include file, it means it can't find the file.  Possible reasons:
1. The file doesn't exist (probably a bad installation of the programming language)
2. The programming language doesn't know how to find that include file (again, probably a bad installation)
3. The file name has been misspelled in some way (it may require you to include the correct file extension as part of the file name, depending on the particular C++ installation you're using)
If it's none of the above, then I don't know and I hope someone with more experience can and will help you.

replies.author: DJ Samke
replies.text:
c++ if you want to do the most complex programming assignments. Java if you're interested in the mundane things. Now someone might disagree and say "Well you can do complex things in java; Android was build with java". Well then my answer will be "Android is part and parcel of the mundane programs I'm talking about". If you want to build search engines, viruses, anti-viruses (malware in general), operating systems, web-servers, IOT software etc., you can do these things in other programming languages, but you will always wish you used c++ (consciously, if you know what c++ can do, and indirectly if you don't know much c++). So just do c++ and you can use javascript if you want to do web-development. 


**Additional** don't fall into what i call "The python trap"

topLevelComment.author: pedantic79
topLevelComment.text: Sorry, but 10:20 and I have to downvote it for using endl. You really should avoid using endl because endl does two things. Sends '\n' to the stream and then flushes it. This really isn't what you want to do, 99% of the time. And in the 1% of the time you would want to flush you should use std::flush. So instead of cout << "Hello world!" << endl;, it should be cout << "Hello world!\n" << flush;

replies.author: pedantic79
replies.text: Peterolen The big reason to key in on this is that it shows a lack of knowledge about modern c++. By modern C++ I mean C++11 and later. Idiomatic code C++98 and C++03 is no longer considered idiomatic. Endl is perhaps the smallest and most simple of these things.

topLevelComment.author: MycroSparks
topLevelComment.text: You should really write pointers with the star going after the data type (int* pAge, double* pGpa...), otherwise it gets beginners confused as to why *pAge shows the value at the address later on in the code, meanwhile at it's initialization, which you wrote in the same way, there's *pAge = &x. Just makes it confusing, and is the wrong way of doing it too, since you're making a data type int pointer, you're not derefferencing the variable.

topLevelComment.author: JG124
topLevelComment.text:
Great video, but I have a question. When I save the project, and it saves the exe file of the program I made, if I try to run it without Codeblocks then it crashes. If I open up Codeblocks first, and use Codeblocks to run the program, it will run just fine. Why does this happen?


edit: I fixed it. For anyone else who has this problem, at the end of your code right above Return 0, you have to include 2 lines of code. The first one is cin.ignore() and the 2nd one is cin.get(). Put those in your code right above Return 0 and you should be good.

replies.author: JG124
replies.text: @Rohin Kumar No it actually wasn't edited, when you replied it reminded me to edit it so thanks, lol.

replies.author: Rohin Kumar
replies.text: @JG124 ohk gud.. Actually i didn't see ur edit part..of ur comment

replies.author: JG124
replies.text: @Rohin Kumar Yeah I figured it out. It wasn't crashing. It was just closing before the user had a chance to read the result. I found out by running the exe with Powershell. Once I figured out it worked when I did that, I looked up a fix and found out I had to include cin.ignore() and then cin.get(). It works fine now.

replies.author: MrTheRocketmaster
replies.text: In case you haven't solved the problem yet. There are multiple versions to choose from, some don't include the compiler, it's easy to miss. Choose the one that says "codeblocks-17.12mingw-setup.exe". Pay attention to the "mingw" part, because that is, in fact, the compiler.

topLevelComment.author: Thomas Weston
topLevelComment.text: for anyone having trouble with the "GNU GCC Compiler" not functioning properly or not being located in the proper directory upon installation: Click settings in the top menu, compiler, on the left of the new window make sure you're in Global Compiler Settings, then in the main window click "toolchain executables" (should be over what looks like a search bar), then next to the bar labeled "compiler's installation directory" click "auto-detect". For whatever reason upon every installation, even leaving everything default, my compiler directory would be messed up. This fixed my issue so i wanted to share in case anyone else had a weird install.

topLevelComment.author: Shut-in Gaming
topLevelComment.text:
Awesome tutorial video for an indispensable language! Everyone should learn C++ but *ALMOST* no one should be using C++ imo.
Before everyone jumps down my throat, let me justify that opinion XD
 
There are 2 main reasons why one would choose to use C/C++ to develop a piece of software and those 2 reasons are also 2 reasons why people should avoid it in most instances.

1.) C/C++ has unmatched memory management given to the user that almost or no language higher gives the coder. This also means you're required to manage resources on your own for even the smallest of programs.

2.) C/C++ compiles to native binaries which runs extremely fast. However, this comes at the expense of rapid development. Ask yourself this; are you willing to sacrifice rapid development for an application speed increase that the vast majority of the time, won't even be noticeable to the end user ?( in most cases minded, data crunching large data sets will obviously yield much more favorable results for C/C++ )

A note about pointers. Don't know if it was due to trying to explain pointers as simply as possible but the explanation wasn't quite on point so here goes;

&var_name gives you a memory address to where your value is being stored.
*ptr_name gives you a memory address to where an address to where &var_name is being stored which changes if the address for var_name ever changes.

&var_name = your street address to where your house is located.
*ptr_name = a P.O Box with your street address inside to where your house is located.

with *ptr_name, your house can change; expand, or shrink, your address can change but you still keep the same P.O Box that's automatically updated with the new address.

topLevelComment.author: Sir Antoweif
topLevelComment.text:
This tutorial is great for beginners, thanks! All the repetition throughout the course is great for watching and learning.


Learning is not a race. Most guides / tutorials will only say things once, and then expect you to be a complete master of it and maybe similar commands the next time they use them. When these crash courses get to part 2, they will be way way beyond beginner level. Although all the information needed is there and explained. Beginners won't be able to use the "learned" information properly that way, because they haven't formed an idea of what they saw and what it meant. They got the answer, no problem. However. Only a copy of the answer, nothing more.


If a tutorial doesn't go into great length about boring details you "already know about", then you know it isn't a good one. If you don't need that, then just skip the detailed parts or find a tutorial meant for those who already mastered what you're trying to learn. I bet you'll end up back where you started though, since you will need to read up again on the boring basics to understand what they are actually talking about. Though not in great length this time, no no, because those who mastered something went into serious and tedious length to research the details of the details of the basics, to be able to master what they do. It isn't the fancy stuff that will get you far. It is the details. Don't skip out on them.

topLevelComment.text: *What's the difference between a void function and a function with return keyword... They're are completely the same, besides "return" and also when do you use the certain function?*

replies.author: Derp Dude
replies.text:
@Shry uwu yes, in smaller programs it looks like they almost do the same thing, especially in these examples he gives. But, when you move on to bigger programs, and you deal with objects, the difference is clear. Look at the getters and setters section. 
             
Quick example, when you call .length() on a string that .length() method is actually a function that returns an int, allowing you to get the length of the string. If it were a void, you would not be able to get this information without running the program and printing to the console which is just unnecessary and a waste of space.

replies.author: Jtag Solutions
replies.text: Personally for me I use Unity, a lot of people will give gripe that unreal is better and that unreal has better graphics but I always saw it two ways. Unreal is for artists who want to create pretty things out the box where as Unity is for programmers, however I do not doubt UE capabilities and the fact it also includes C++ rather than just blue prints is fantastic I do find that to be a selling point when it comes down to beginners as you can use blue print for free to build something then learn C++ to do it all properly once you get to grips with the editor however with some small additions to unity such as the post processing stack and even the HDRP you can create just as beautiful looking scenes and games as you could with Unreal the main thing with Unity is that "blue prints" per se dont exist unless you purchase an add on such as play maker so out of the box you have to delve into C# if you dont want to buy 3rd party assets. As a programmer I found the UE interface to be a bit child like and gimmicky compared to the more monotone basic look of unity however both engines are more than capable of doing what you need for pretty much any game style you just have to learn to make it do what you need ! :) Happy learning and I hope whatever you do pick you have success with !

replies.author: Jtag Solutions

replies.author: Chubbzchannel
replies.text: I'm working in ue4 and learning c++ at the same time. It's constantly surprising how the visual scripting system, and c++ compliment each other, although they're very different in practice. Everything I learn in the editor helps me along with c++ and in c++ helps me in visual scripting. I was so overwhelmed 3 months ago but now I have the ability to debug my game in vs or editor, it's awesome to live in this age where information is so readily available, free. Cheers to all us amateur developers or aspiring developers and those who are willing to coach us.

what are those two arrows in which the codes are typed??
I MEAN THESE <<     >>

replies.author: anti/HUMAN Designs
replies.text:
They are "bitwise shift" operators. They shift bits in a value to the sides.
But with std::cout, std::cin, and other such things, those operators have been overloaded to perform a different function.
"std::cout << X" is essentially the same as "cout.function(X)". It just calls a function in the std::cout object.

topLevelComment.author: Norce555
topLevelComment.text: Learning a lot of stuff here but when you want to offer different ways of explaining something, make sure that you can actually do that. This video has lots of repetition of the same sentence over and over for that very reason. Like in this quote: "This is where classes and objects come in. What we can do is we can actually create a class, and a class is essentially a new data type, so when I create a class I'm basically creating a new data type in C++, and that's really why classes are useful because we can kinda create a blueprint for a new type of data in our program". Then just one minute later you say "And I'm gonna create a class. And a class is essentially just a specification or a blueprint for a new data type in our program. So when I create a class I'm basically creating a new data type. I'm creating a new type of data that we can work with and use in our programs". All of this is basically "A class is a data type" five or six times over. Focus on either finding varied explanations, or just cutting down the number of words to give it to us straight. But still, thank you!

topLevelComment.author: Robert Lawton
topLevelComment.text: re: 3:10:00 pointers are handy when you want a function to return an array. Functions can't return arrays in c++, but they can return a pointer to a static array created in the function. It's not very transparent, but that's how it works.

replies.author: Michael Thompson
replies.text:
Allocating an array on the stack (ie, within a function call without “new” or malloc) and then returning that pointer that points to the first element of the array is a bad idea.

Stacks grow as function calls are made . Each function call gets a new context on the stack, and after the function is done executing the stack space is “freed”. Any local variables allocated during that function call are also freed, including the pointer to the array you just created and returned.

If you return a pointer allocated on the stack that has been freed, then you will be accessing memory that is in stack space that has already been “deallocated” and is subject to modification when new function calls being made. Your data might still be there in physical memory for some time, but over time the program may overwrite the memory (and/or malicious users of your program looking to exploit your code).

topLevelComment.author: LoCloud7
topLevelComment.text:
You should mention that "using namespace std;" is really only acceptable for very small programs. You should *not* use it if your program will do non-trivial work, as you will likely get naming collision of your functions with the standard library. Instead, always prefix standard library functions or types with std::
(Trust me, it's not that hard to get used to and you'll avoid a ton of bugs)

For, say, print-heavy functions, you could prefix the code *inside* a function with "using std::cout; using std::endl;" to then not have to write std::cout and std::endl all the time (instead only writing cout and endl)

And finally, don't overuse std::endl. Most of the time all you want is to add a \n. This is because std::endl flushes the output, which is slower than just writing a newline character to the stream (my benchmark for instance yielded 100% speed improvement using \n over std::endl)

replies.author: skaruts
replies.text:
I never had my own functions conflicting with the standard lib. Been "using namespace"s all along and never had any issues at all. I'm not an expert c++ coder, and I don't use many libs (SDL, SFML...), but then so don't most people who are learning to program. I think it's more productive if they keep their code clean and be taught to *understand* the caveats if an when they delve into using more 3rd party libs.

Besides, nothing replaces learning from mistakes. If I ever have issues with using namespaces, I'll see exactly why it is.
